abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Mizoram State Roads
            Project for India were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            inclusion of too many components in a project (six in this
            case) negatively affects implementation, because both the
            client and the Bank have limited resources for effective
            supervision and implementation. When clients have limited
            capacity to begin with, it may be prudent to limit
            components to fewer with a similar implementation format.
            Similarly, the project should not have too many indicators.
            Fewer, measurable and objective monitoring indicators and a
            well designed evaluation system will better assess the
            baselines and subsequently achievement of project outcomes.
            Special measures should also be introduced to ensure top
            caliber consultants are appointed when local capacity is
            weak. In this case inferior consultants paid on a time basis
            were in effect rewarded because of the project delays. The
            project should have adequate contingency arrangements in
            line with Bank norms. Bio-engineering measures using local
            bamboo and traditional techniques may be used to stabilize
            landslide-prone hill sides. This promotes local employment
            generation. The success of using such techniques in this
            project has led to replication in areas such as Himachal
            Pradesh. Debris disposed in an environmentally friendly
            manner can also benefit the community. In the Mizoram
            project the debris provided a unique opportunity to create
            football pitches and water storage ponds for the local community.
